awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: LTREB RENEWAL: EVOLUTIONARY DEMOGRAPHY - THE CONTRIBUTION OF ADAPTATION AND ENVIRONMENT TO POPULATION DYNAMICS, RANGE SIZE, AND NICHE WIDTH
awd_abstract_narration:
A fundamental objective of ecology and evolutionary biology is to explain the geographic distributions of species. But species are dynamic entities, and their geographic distributions respond to changing environments. If the environment of their suitable habitat changes, populations of a species can sustain themselves in their current habitat by adaption through natural selection, or they need to shift to new locations. Understanding the mechanisms that account for species distributions is especially timely because of the accelerating pace of environmental change. The contribution of adaptation to population dynamics, local persistence, and to the geographic range inhabited by a species, has rarely been quantified. Although comparative ecological studies and species distribution models typically assume genetic uniformity across a species geographic range, genetic studies have repeatedly demonstrated local adaptation. This project explicitly examines the contribution of adaptation to population growth and the extent of a species geographic range, through the continuation of a long-term field population demographic study and the use of a species distribution model. The project will also involve outreach to a rural middle school, engaging students in research activities, and it will connect citizens to research scientists through an innovative outreach program, Market Science, where researchers engage the public at farmer's markets. 

The research team will focus on a well-studied California native plant species, Clarkia xantiana, which has been the focus of intensive field research for over 12 years. This research will provide new, exceptionally detailed information about how species' ranges evolve and the factors that are likely to influence species responses to climate variation. The specific objectives of this project are to examine: (1) whether population dynamics vary from the center to margins of the species' range and what environmental factors drive this variation; (2) the spatial scale of local adaptation and how it relates to demographic similarity among populations; and (3) the interplay of population dynamics and adaptation in shaping environmental tolerances (niche width) and geographic range size. Only long-term studies can provide robust predictions about what controls population persistence, evolutionary adaptation, and their consequences for species ranges. Long-term demographic datasets of vital rates (e.g. survival, reproduction), population growth, and abiotic and biotic (herbivory) factors, have been collected in 35 natural populations spanning the major portion of the species' range. All monitoring of field populations will be continued an additional ten years. Past work has examined local adaptation using a large reciprocal transplant experiment among demographically-divergent populations. This experiment will be repeated in the project's second five-year phase.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This study focused on the relationship between a population’s long-term demography – whether population size is stable through time or how fast a population is growing or declining in size – and how well it is locally adapted to its. Theory suggests that population demography and local adaptation should be linked. For example, a population may be declining because it is poorly adapted to its home site, or a declining population may be small and therefore lack sufficient genetic variation to adapt to local conditions. Conversely, stable or growing populations may reflect high local adaptation, or such populations may sustain sufficient genetic variation to adapt to local conditions. The linkage between population demography and local adaptation has rarely been examined in natural settings through long term studies of populations. Understanding the linkage between demography and local adaptation is important for several reasons. If the linkage is strong, estimates of population growth rate can be used as proxies for local adaptation (and vice versa) and could inform where to source seeds for restoration programs for populations that have been extirpated by disturbance, such as fire. Additionally, an understanding of the linkage between demography and local adaptation is important to our understanding of how populations may respond to environmental change.

 

Long-term population growth rates were estimated for multiple populations of the California annual plant, Clarkia xantiana ssp.  xantiana, based on yearly censuses of plant survival and reproductive success and the survival and germination of seeds in the Kern River region of the southern Sierra Nevada of California. Local adaptation was measured by transplanting seeds from the same populations into their home sites and to away sites in two separate years and comparing performance at home versus away. Locally adapted populations should perform better at home than at away sites. As predicted, declining populations were poorly locally adapted, while stable populations had high levels of local adaptation. Surprisingly, growing populations also had low levels of local adaptation. One possible explanation is that rapid population growth may be driven by benign environmental conditions that are similarly favorable for all genotypes, resulting in relaxed selection and reduced local adaptation and/or maladaptation. Alternatively, if growing populations have recently colonized a site, rare deleterious genetic variants can increase during population expansion. The causes of low local adaptation in growing populations deserves further study.

 

We also asked whether the level of local adaptation was related to three metrics of similarity between home and away sites: 1) the history of selection on vital rates, 2) the abiotic environment, or 3) the geographic proximity of the sites. All three metrics of site similarity explained levels of local adaptation, but their explanatory power was weak.

 

Our studies also examined geographic variation among populations in the rates of seed germination and survival in the soil. While Clarkia xantiana ssp.  xantiana plants live only a single year above ground, seeds are long lived. In any given winter, only a small fraction of seeds produced the previous summer germinate in response to winter rains, while the rest remain dormant. Seed dormancy is expected to be adaptive in variable environments where plant survival and reproductive success vary greatly from year to year, and there is risk of complete reproductive failure. Under such conditions, seed dormancy should be highest in populations experiencing the greatest risk of reproductive failure and seed survival in the soil is highest. Using new statistical methods that we developed to accurately quantify seed vital rates (survival in the soil, germination from the seed bank), and long-term data on above ground plant survival and reproductive success from 20 populations, seed dormancy was found to be adaptive is in some populations, but dormancy levels were much higher than expected. Separate studies found that seeds from populations with greater risk of reproductive failure require higher moisture levels to germinate, indicative of better growing conditions, than do seeds form population with lower risk of reproductive failure. It appears therefore that populations have evolved germination requirements that match their history of demographic risk.

 

The project engaged students of varying educational experience (12 undergraduates, 6 postgraduates, 4 graduate students, 1 postdoctoral fellow) in fieldwork, independent research, and professional training. Many of these former students pursued advanced degrees and are working in scientific fields in and outside of academia or in education. Findings from the work have been disseminated in academic journals (19 publications), presentations at national and international meetings (12 talks), and in classroom teaching. We also partnered with the local high school and middle school in the Kern River region to offer demonstrations of our work and gave presentations to lay audiences through Native Plant Societies and Botanic Gardens.
